awd_titl_txt: Level Crossing of Likelihood Functions in Sequential Decision Problems and Statistical Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
The last decade has witnessed remarkable progress in statistical methods for applications arising from various fields including education, psychology, finance, and engineering. The properties of many of these new methods remain unclear, calling for theoretical insights. This research project aims at (1) studying the theoretical underpinning of effective methods in statistical learning and sequential decision making and (2) developing new methods with provably efficiency and reliability.  This research will not only address a class of fundamental problems in statistics but also have a positive impact on scientific research in other disciplines. One important application will be in the adaptive design of educational testing and personalized learning. 

Three types of problems will be considered in the project: information quantification for model selection, measuring the feasibility of classification, and sequential allocation. A common feature of the research problems involves handling the probability that a likelihood function exceeds a high level. The analysis of such a probability is statistically challenging, especially under the asymptotic regime where this probability decays at an exponential rate. Standard numerical evaluation tools, such as Monte Carlo methods, are computationally intensive to achieve a reasonable accuracy level for simulating such a small probability. Novel techniques will be developed to obtain sharp asymptotic approximations as well as provably efficient numerical methods simultaneously.

por.por_cntn:
This research program develops novel statistical methods and theoretical results for sequential decision-making problems and statistical learning. The methodological contributions include a binary classification method for crowdsourced data which allows early stopping and worker selection, a sequential rank aggregation method for inferring the global rank of multiple objects based on their pairwise comparisons, sequential hypothesis testing methods when there are multiple data streams under communication constraints, and estimation and information quantification methods for statistical models involving latent variables. The theoretical contributions include the analysis of level-crossing probabilities for random functions of different types, optimality theory for sequential methods, and new technical tools such as a change-of-measure technique for stochastic processes, which may be reused for similar problems.

In addition to the contributions to the field of statistics, this research program also has a positive impact on other fields including education, psychology, marketing, and engineering. For example, the sequential methods developed in this research program can be applied in educational testing and individualized learning. During the project period, the PI has more than ten published/accepted papers at peer-reviewed journals including the Journal of the American Statistical Association, Biometrika, Annals of Applied Probability, IEEE Information Theory, and Psychometrika. The results of the project have been presented at academic conferences in statistics, applied probability, psychometrics, and engineering. Papers and statistical software have been made available online. The PI has advised (and is advising) graduate students, and has incorporated the methodological ideas of this research program in teaching.
